title: My 3YO is not cooperating with his potty training. We have done our best to train him (videos, demos with toys, reassurance, etc.). Nothing seems to be working. He will be starting kindergarten next year and we are worried. What should we do? - Quora

response.answer_text: Look, I'm going to tell you what to do, but you might not like it. Okay, here goes, give your kid an M and M candy, just one, out of the bag, every time they go potty. But, your kid must have their own little potty toilet to do this. The reason is, because they have to sit there until they pee or poop or both. And as soon as they do, clap for them, and tell them that you're so so happy they did it, then wash up and give them a candy. If your kid doesn't like MandMs then reward them with whatever you want. Sooner or later, they are going to go without being rewarded. It just takes time. The fact that they have to sit there isn't fun, because someone has to sit there with them. But, someone does have to sit there with them or none of this is going to work. Also, at nap time and bed time put a pull up's on him. And always only underwear any other time. The diapers no longer exist. Believe me, a kid will not potty train with a diaper or pull up on when they're playing. It makes it easy to be lazy. And they hate peeing in underwear. But also, with our son, I would only have him in underwear during the summer time and warm day's and let him out to play in the backyard, and tell him to pick a tree and go pee. I didn't give a damn what anyone thought. If they didn't like it then they could train him at their house and bring him back. Haahaa! But if you don't have a backyard to let him loose on then just be consistently asking him if he has to go yet, to tell you when he does, and he will get his candy when he does. Do not let him see the bag though. Make him think there is only one piece of candy in the house. Otherwise, he will cry for the whole bag. Just say you got this one piece at the store and he can have it when he goes. Remember, there will be accidents, do not get mad when that happens or your kid will not know what to think. It will totally confuse him actually going pee but getting in trouble for it. Sounds weird but, these things I know about. Trust me. So, I want to wish you the best of luck with it all. You don't have to do what I said, I just told you what worked for me with our two kid's. Just don't forget to tell him how proud you are of him when he goes on the potty. And let him help put on his underwear and pull up because it makes them feel more grown up, so to speak. Sorry this is so long but I needed you to know. Take care

We bribed our first-born with the promise of Daddy making her a cake for her first peeing in the toilet this. This worked, but do think that I had erred by focusing initially on her “Keeping her big girl panties dry”. She could be dry for hours and hours, but was not ABLE to pee until the diaper went back on. The message here is to be sure that the child knows that the pee and poops go in the toilet. After the wrong approach above, we put the child potty seat outside, where she played most of the time, and with her wearing no panties or diaper. Pretty easy to notice that she was wetting her legs, so I could get her to the toilet and she could pee and she could get her cake. An instant phone to Dad after the first event, and several times during the day to remind her. That was the turning point! Just be sure that what you are doing is clear to the child. It is not about keeping him dry, but making sure that he uses the toilet. Wherever he is, have a little potty chair nearby, and remember that he really needs to see/feel the impact of peeing on himself, if you can tolerate a few puddles. Of course, if it is too easy for him to pee in his diaper, and not interrupt his play or such, then that is what he will do. After all, that has worked ‘all his life’. I can guarantee you that seeing other little boys use the toilet is important, too. Can you borrow a friend or cousin who is ‘such a big boy’ to use the toilet and let him be a highly visible role model? At nursery schools, ,most often the toilets are quite low so that a tiny child can be independent in reaching the toilet, and they are often unisex. They are generally open to the classroom, so they can be monitored, and EASY to get to from the play area. A low sink to facilitate hand-washing in also part of the process. He will learn, I promise. Nothing is more hard on a boy’s ego than to be the ‘baby’ who doesn’t use the toilet.

What I did was , as soon as the child was aware of going to the bathroom(shows discomfort, pulls at diaper, stops and looks down at what is happening while doing his /her after bath dancing in the buff) I put those thin, terry cloth undies(do they even make those anymore?) on them. Of course do this when you will be home for the day(perfect situation with Covid). The child urinates, the undies are sopping, they walk around like their straddling a horse as they look down at the visual transformation of what is hanging on their bodies. I say “oops, what happened ? You best go into the bathroom. What do you need to do? Take off your pants. They’re very wet” . This is key. Child MUST do this her/himself. Even better if they struggle a bit as it will make a more lasting impression. I then say “ Sit on the potty. Go pee pee. (Of course, they won’t go because they just have. But you’re creating an association.). Then I say “ put your WET pants in the laundry(child must do this). Now go get some DRY pants( child must do this) and put them on. REPEAT this ALL day for several days and longer. Commit yourself to being consistent. All three of my kids (2 boys and a girl) were potty trained within 3 weeks. I have no idea why each one was 3 weeks but I am known as the Queen of Consistency. Parents struggle with potty training because the child is carted from one activity to another all day everyday. I watched my grown children with this. I could have helped them but they were trying to “fit in” potty training into their busy days. Consequently, it went on and on and on….. Be Aware—— it can become a power struggle. But that’s another conversation. P.S. A 3 year old in kindergarten? Remember that he’s just spent his time on earth learning to walk, talk, feed himself and navigate his own little world. Give him time to practice all these newly acquired skills. Be cognizant of that his pace in doing things might not coincide with your pace.

I would stop trying for a month or 2. Then when you are about to start again, put him in underwear, no pull ups! I used cloth diapers and it was easier because kids can’t feel the wet disposable diaper! Now the only thing is, if your child doesn’t care if he is wet or not, then potty training is going to be hard, but I wouldn’t give up! Diaper or pull up can be worn only at bedtime, otherwise, underwear where he can feel being wet or poopy! If you can catch him going on the potty, make a big deal about it with a special treat so he will do it again! If you can wake him in the morning & get him on the potty right away, that may help. I knew when my kids were ready to potty train because they would come & tell me they were wet! But again, they knew they were wet because they could feel it with cloth diapers. You have to keep trying, he will get it.

Well, not all children are the same and some get the idea of what a potty is for sooner than others. I do wonder if, when parents get anxious and try to push the child, it can be counter-productive as the child senses the anxiety and associates the potty with tension and stress—and unhappiness. It could be worth backing off for a while and trying to relax. Perhaps, as someone has suggested, have several potties about the house. Anyway, try to keep the atmosphere free from stress and be extremely patient. I knew a 3-year-old who didn’t get the idea of what a potty was for, and eventually when she began to give it a go, she was given a lot of very positive encouragement and praise. Then she seemed to progress quite quickly. The great thing is to try not to worry. You have time before kindergarten starts next year.

I would have to say, just put him back in a diaper and give it a month and then try it again. He may not be ready and he may be telling you that with his resistance. You can’t force something that a child is not ready for. In a month , try again and maybe this time he will have had enough time to be ready. I know he is 3yrs old and you are probably trying to get him trained as soon as possible but, a child will always win when it comes to potty training, that is the one thing they can control in their lives. Just be patient and take a step back and try again later. No kid goes to kindergarten in diapers. Good luck

I would make an with your pediatrician to make sure that there is nothing wrong and to get advice about this. It could just be laziness on his part because, from what I understand, boys are often harder to potty train than girls. However, he make not have yet correlated and understood the signals his body gives him to tell him he needs to go pee and/or poop. Has dad taken him into the bathroom and physically showed him what big boys do when they have to pee? If not, you might try that and see if it helps. I am not a mother but my friends have talked to me about what they went through with their children. But first, you need to have your pediatrician check him out to make sure that this is not health related.

Maybe he is just not ready yet, and there’s no need to force him. Does he tell you when he needs to go toilet, big and small? Does he tell before he do it or only after? If he doesn’t say it before he’s probably not ready yet, and if he does say it before, then maybe just find some other solutions for him to be interested in going to the toilet. Just have some patience with him - I would say that the more he feel like you are forcing him or putting all this over him the more he will dislike it. Is there a problem with him going kindergarten and still wearing a nappy?

You are taking this too seriously, and I suspect your child is overwhelmed. Give him a high fiber diet, and if his diet is limited, then there are “crackers” which had a fiber that helps with elimination. He may be resistant, constipated, or just wants to do this on his own schedule. Tell him that you are waiting for him to grow up and take care of this on is own, but it is up to him. You know that many four year old boys are not ready for kindergarten either, so I wouldn’t consider him to need more time. Make sure he has enough friends, exercise and lack of stress.

He’s not quite ready yet if he is resistant. Relax, take him every two hours or 20 minutes after drinking something but only let him sit there for five minutes at a time, no longer. Be matter of fact but don’t act annoyed or angry. Talk about how big boys use the potty and maybe some other things that big boys get to do after they learn to go to the potty - something he would like to do. Use a good attitude and make a big deal when he goes in the potty.

you have to make it uncomfortable for him to continue with the same behavior. For my daughter, luckily it took only one try, but she would not go number 2 in a toilet. She would hide in isolated area then walk around like nothing happened. After tiring of her way, we allowed her to walk around with that messed up rear and we never had the problem again. Not telling you to do what I did but if you find a way to make it uncomfortable for him to continue I don’t think it will last long

When he “gets it” the potty training will click in. Don’t worry about it a year in advance. Boys are generally slower at this than girls and 3yo is not at all unusual. You may want to wait another few months before trying again. Also, have you considered not sending him to kindergarten when he is 4? I think boys are too young at that age to learn as well as they could at 5. You may be setting him up to be at a significant disadvantage if he starts school that young.

These things do not happen on demand, in fact you could be over doing the encouragement and holding him back. The fact that you are blaming him for ‘not cooperating - is a worry. Just relax. Let him relax. It could happen suddenly - but in his own time. You still have almost three months. And if he goes to kindergarten in pull-ups - or whatever you call the plastic pants - that’s okay. Talk to the teacher. He might not be the only one.

You can't force that which he is obviously not ready for. He may be rebelling against your efforts. A lot of parents often have success with “Oh Crap- potty training” book. Also check with doctor what they recommend. If a toddler has bowel issues, they'll also be nervous about the potty. Many 3 yr olds aren't fully potty trained.
Home school him! Kindergarten is mostly about getting along with others anyway. You can find other ways to socialize him. Don't let deadlines freak you out… just don't get on that hamster treadmill.

I’d recommend you do two things. First ask his pediatrician if there is anything physically making his potty training difficult. Second, back off. Stop pushing him. He has learned that he has control, TOTAL control, of this one thing in his life, and he’s using it. When he wants to use the potty, he will. He surely understands that you want him to.

Stop getting so intense about it - the more you push the less he will co-operate. Just make sure you put him in big boy pants every day so he FEELS what happens when he doesn’t go to the toilet. Also try using the big toilet (with a child seat) rather than a potty - this sometimes makes it more REAL for a toddler.
Let him go unchanged. He will become very uncomfortable and ask for a change. THEN an explanation will stick.
In all honesty I would take a break and then try again in a month m,you're putting too much pressure on him and he is not ready.
Take a break, he’s obviously not ready yet. Once there’s not so much pressure on him to perform, he may do it himself. Good luck.
